Interpol's fourth LP is their triumphant
return to Matador Records after being on
Capitol for a short stint of one album
and if you put your ears on this thing
sound wise Interpol really isn't
throwing too much at you that they
haven't before in some ways it's pretty
much what you've come to expect from the
band of course that very eerie hallow
sound of course that very eerie bleak
hallow atmosphere is on this LP to the
sound that's been kind of following them
since their first release their
critically acclaimed turn on the bright
lights and I guess another depressing
thing is that this LP kind of follows
suit with the trend that has been
happening on Interpol's music in terms
of Carlos danglers bass lines just
getting turned lower and lower and lower
into the mix here they're kind of
quieter than ever but still they're
pursuing that moody rock sound that is
influenced by bands like of course Joy
Division and I love that about Interpol
I'm glad they're still working with that
aesthetic it works for them it's earned
then the fan base that they have thus
far and made their music the treat that
it has been for the past four albums the
biggest change you'll find on this LP is
how the band is structuring their songs
this time around which is exemplified by
a track like let's say lights the band
is really pursuing a lot of building and
a lot of repetition in their music on
this LP instead of changing up sounds
when the verse comes or the chorus comes
they switch in between a bridge or
something like that the whole song just
kind of builds instrumentation and
builds instrumentation this is kind of
shown up in the form of lots of horns
strings piano tremolo Pickett ARS lots
of reverb - I wouldn't say Interpol has
gone orchestral or shoegaze or drone or
anything like that but I would say that
they're sounding a lot less like a rock
band there's not really any raw energy
or power to this LP for me it's all safe
and a little dreary - there are a few
spots on this LP though where it feels
kind of like the old-school Interpol
kind of like on the track barricade
great dance beat good hook and Paul
banks vocals for me are a little off but
still very emotive however a lot of the
extra sounds a lot of the experiments on
this LP don't exactly go over all that
well you've got these sequences
electronics with the track try it on a
very droney and theatrical atmosphere
with all of the waves and the album
closes with the undoing which features
singing in a different language I don't
know which one I'm not a linguist and
some vocal samples - which were kind of
disorienting it's almost as if most of
the time the band is like oh let's do
this weird sound let's throw in this
weird repetition let's just try this new
thing which isn't necessarily bad trying
new things however I'm just kind of
sitting here thinking man I just kind of
want you to write a good song and that's
where my number-one gripe and kind of my
verdict for this album comes in a
repetition like I mentioned earlier a
lot of repetition on this LP with the
building of the tracks and repetition
not necessarily a bad thing but in this
instance it's for me very underwhelming
ah I'm sure a lot of people have been
but I can't say I'm really all that
angry or offended by this album it's not
disgustingly awful
I think hardcore Interpol fans may even
enjoy this probably even more than Paul
banks solo album that he came out with
last year so if you're diggin it all the
more power to you I have nothing against
you but when listening to this maybe for
the exception of two or three tracks I
am so bored
by the lack of contrast in most of the
hooks and just the monotony of these
songs
so really I'm feeling a decent too
